bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 28, 1929

div1.p: Carter waits for Frost to get back to his work on the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever. Carter and Brown continue to turn up a few of the more elusive references for the book.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 28, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
March 28, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have put in an unusually satisfactory week's
work, despite the fact that I have done my share with “one eye” on the
telephone and the other on the mail box, hoping for a summons to
Baltimore with my material for the resumption of the final editing.
A long distance message from Mrs. Frost, however, states that Dr.
Frost will not be able to resume this work until after Easter, so
Miss Brown and I shall continue to concentrate on our few remaining
unverified references, which, despite the “law of diminishing returns”
are still giving returns of a kind to justify the hard work and long
hours we are putting in to get them. In this connection, I am de-
lighted to state that Miss Brown did finally verify our long-sought
reference in Walckenaer re “aigris” (sic) beads, our single verified
card thereon representing many nights of hard work both in Walckenaer's
“Collection”...parallel reading etc. N. B. She has just called me
up to tell me of another verification of a particular reference re
the voyage of Hanno, the Carthagenian, which we had almost despaired of
of ever listing among our “returns.” Miss Brown is certainly both
ingenious and persistent in this work. I've had some good luck myself
too. Indeed, I am sure that you will be well pleased with the result
of our work when you see it.
I spent most of last Tuesday at the Library of Congress:

(1) To check up Miss Brown's findings in Walckenaer's “Col-
lection”...already referred to, as well as all her parallel data (in-
cluding Bosman's “Description of the Coast of Guinea”...of which Walcke
account is an abstract. This because Walckenaer's account of the “aigris
“aigris” beads
is less detailed than our ref. in Father's MS, so we had to copy the
sources of the extra data for Dr. Frost.

(2) Another reason for going to the Library of Congress is
that I have been working so steadily at home, and for so long a time,
that I felt it would be advisable to appear at my desk at the Library
lest I lose my reservation there, which would be a real handicap. Of
course, it is a great convenience to have my desk and table at the
Library, as I am able to keep together the bulk of my reference
books, thus having them ready to hand instead of having to get them
one by one from the stacks. Also Miss Brown can work up there after
hours and we shall both need the space, and books, when we are going[unclear]
over the proof--which time may Heaven hasten!
div1.closer:
With best wishes for Baster, I remain
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
